meta.description: Enhanced guidance rules for the SOQL helper, structured to follow SELECT → FROM → WHERE → ORDER BY → LIMIT.

emptySuggestion.title: Write a focused SOQL query
emptySuggestion.message: Start by selecting a small field list and limit the records you pull back. Use WHERE and LIMIT to keep results manageable.

rules.title: Avoid SELECT *
rules.message: SOQL does not support SELECT * and listing many fields increases payload size.
rules.suggestion: List the specific fields you need instead of using *.

rules.title: Select specific fields
rules.message: Specify only the fields you need for this query to reduce payload and improve performance.
rules.suggestion: List only the fields needed, e.g., SELECT Id, Name FROM Account.

rules.title: Specify a valid object
rules.message: The FROM clause must reference a valid Salesforce object (for example: Account).
rules.suggestion: Ensure you include one valid object name after FROM.

rules.title: Filter your query
rules.message: Filtering reduces returned rows and speeds up queries.
rules.suggestion: Add a WHERE clause that narrows the records you need.

rules.title: Query lacks filtering
rules.message: Unfiltered queries can return too many records and hurt performance.
rules.suggestion: Add a WHERE clause to reduce result size.

rules.title: Pair ORDER BY with LIMIT
rules.message: ORDER BY can be expensive without a LIMIT; consider adding LIMIT when ordering.
rules.suggestion: Use LIMIT when ordering to keep results manageable.

rules.title: Add a LIMIT clause
rules.message: SOQL queries without LIMIT can pull more data than expected; add a LIMIT to bound results.
rules.suggestion: Append LIMIT <n> to control how many records are returned.

rules.title: Include related-object fields
rules.message: If you need data from a related object, select related fields using dot-notation (for example: Owner.Name) instead of separate queries.
rules.suggestion: Select related fields when appropriate, e.g., SELECT Id, Name, Owner.Name FROM Account.

rules.title: COUNT() queries
rules.message: COUNT() returns a single aggregate row and is efficient when you only need a total.
rules.suggestion: Use COUNT() when you only need the record count.
